claims.text: The 2015 Paris Agreement aims to limit global warming to well below 2 degrees Celsius, preferably to 1.5 degrees Celsius.
Scientists warn that we need to limit global warming to 1.5 degrees Celsius to reduce climate breakdown consequences.
Human-induced global warming is a major underlying factor for changing weather patterns.
Global CO2 emissions must be halved from 2010 levels by 2030 to meet climate targets.
Earth's weather cycles have become increasingly erratic and severe in recent years.
Increased human consumption of fossil fuels since the industrial revolution has led to more greenhouse gases being released.
Heat waves have more than doubled in duration in the past 50 years.
Heat waves are estimated to be 10 times more likely now according to the UK's Met Office.
Droughts are becoming more common and severe in some areas due to climate change.
Increased rainfall events are becoming heavier across the world, falling in shorter and more intense bursts.
The target of limiting global warming to 1.5 degrees Celsius is increasingly moving out of reach.
Extreme weather is continuing to become more frequent and prevalent globally.
Droughts put added pressure on water supplies as demand increases from agriculture.
Increased rainfall worsens flooding, damaging infrastructure and contaminating groundwater.
Carbon dioxide and methane are greenhouse gases released into Earth's atmosphere.

claim_reports.claim_text: The 2015 Paris Agreement aims to limit global warming to well below 2 degrees Celsius, preferably to 1.5 degrees Celsius.
claim_reports.verdict_summary: The evidence strongly supports the claim that the 2015 Paris Agreement aims to limit global warming to well below 2 degrees Celsius, preferably to 1.5 degrees Celsius, as confirmed by multiple high-reliability sources including the UNFCCC and the IPCC.

supports.title: The Paris Agreement | UNFCCC
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence confirms that the Paris Agreement aims to limit global warming to 1.5 degrees Celsius, stating that greenhouse gas emissions must peak before 2025 and decline significantly by 2030 to achieve this goal.
supports.snippet: To limit global warming to 1.5°C, greenhouse gas emissions must peak before 2025 at the latest and decline 43% by 2030. The Paris Agreement is a landmark in the ...

supports.title: Global Warming of 1.5 ºC —

supports.title: Paris temperature goal - Climate Action Tracker
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence confirms that the Paris Agreement aims to limit global warming to well below 2 degrees Celsius and to pursue efforts to limit the temperature increase to 1.5 degrees Celsius, as stated in its long-term temperature goal.
supports.snippet: The origin of the 1.5°C Paris Agreement limit derived from the concern amongst the vulnerable countries about the adverse consequences of a 2°C warming level.

claim_reports.claim_text: Scientists warn that we need to limit global warming to 1.5 degrees Celsius to reduce climate breakdown consequences.

supports.snippet: Global average temperature was more than 1.5 degrees Celsius warmer than the pre-industrial average for several months in late 2023.

claim_reports.claim_text: Human-induced global warming is a major underlying factor for changing weather patterns.
claim_reports.verdict_summary: The evidence strongly supports the claim that human-induced global warming is a major underlying factor for changing weather patterns. supports.snippet: The US sustained 403 weather and climate disasters from 1980–2024 where overall damages/costs reached or exceeded $1 billion (including CPI adjustment to 2024).

supports.title: Extreme Weather and Climate Change - NASA Science

claim_reports.claim_text: Heat waves are estimated to be 10 times more likely now according to the UK's Met Office.
claim_reports.verdict_summary: The evidence presents a mixed picture regarding the claim that heat waves are now 10 times more likely according to the UK's Met Office. While some sources, including a Met Office blog and a study reported by The Guardian, suggest that heatwaves over 40°C are indeed ten times more likely due to climate change, other high-reliability sources like the BBC and New York Times indicate an increase in frequency and intensity without explicitly confirming the tenfold increase. This inconsistency leads to a mixed assessment.

claim_reports.claim_text: Droughts put added pressure on water supplies as demand increases from agriculture.
claim_reports.verdict_summary: The evidence strongly supports the claim that droughts increase pressure on water supplies due to rising agricultural demands. Multiple high-reliability sources indicate that droughts lead to heightened water demand for irrigation and drinking water, exacerbating water supply issues.

supports.snippet: Drought poses significant challenges to agricultural production. Limited water availability can cause plant stress, leading to reduced crop yields and quality.

claim_reports.claim_text: Carbon dioxide and methane are greenhouse gases released into Earth's atmosphere.
claim_reports.verdict_summary: The evidence strongly supports the claim that carbon dioxide and methane are greenhouse gases released into Earth's atmosphere. NASA confirms both gases trap heat through the greenhouse effect, and the US EPA corroborates this by stating they contribute to greenhouse gas emissions.

supports.title: What Are Greenhouse Gases? - NASA Science
supports.evidence_summary: The article confirms that carbon dioxide and methane are indeed greenhouse gases present in Earth's atmosphere, which trap heat through the greenhouse effect.
supports.snippet: Greenhouse gases are gases in Earth's atmosphere that trap the heat from the sun near the surface of our planet. They do this through a process ...

supports.title: Sources of Greenhouse Gas Emissions | US EPA
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence confirms that carbon dioxide and methane are indeed greenhouse gases that trap heat in Earth's atmosphere, contributing to the greenhouse effect.
supports.snippet: Sources of greenhouse gas emissions, inculding electricity production, tranportation, industry, agriculture, and forestry.

claim_reports.claim_text: Global CO2 emissions must be halved from 2010 levels by 2030 to meet climate targets.
claim_reports.verdict_summary: The evidence presents a mixed picture regarding the claim. The Climate Action Tracker indicates that the US aims for a 50%-52% reduction in emissions by 2030, which supports the need for significant reductions. However, other sources, including the IPCC, suggest a 45% reduction from 2010 levels is necessary, indicating that while the claim aligns with some targets, there is variability in the specific reduction percentages and baseline years.

supports.title: USA - Targets | Climate Action Tracker
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence indicates that the US aims to reduce emissions by 50%–52% below 2005 levels by 2030, which aligns with the claim that global CO2 emissions need to be significantly reduced to meet climate targets, although it specifies a different baseline year than 2010.
supports.snippet: In its Nationally Determined Contribution (NDC), the US has set a target to reduce emissions by 50%–52% below 2005 levels by 2030 (U.S. ...

claim_reports.claim_text: The target of limiting global warming to 1.5 degrees Celsius is increasingly moving out of reach.
claim_reports.verdict_summary: The evidence presents a mixed picture regarding the 1.5 degrees Celsius target. While global temperatures exceeded this threshold temporarily in late 2023 (Climate.gov), and nations are significantly behind on their climate pledges (UNEP report), there remains a theoretical possibility to achieve the target through rapid action (WRI report). However, the substantial emission reductions required (Earth.org) indicate that the target is increasingly challenging to meet.

unclear.title: What's in a number? The meaning of the 1.5-C climate threshold
unclear.evidence_summary: Global average temperature was more than 1.5 degrees Celsius warmer than the pre-industrial average for several months in late 2023.
unclear.snippet: Global average temperature was more than 1.5 degrees Celsius warmer than the pre-industrial average for several months in late 2023.

transcript_data.text: from flooding to heat waves wildfires to droughts our planet has been experiencing more frequent and intense weather events in recent years so how is this connected to climate change and how can we lessen its impact this is decomplicated how is extreme weather connected to climate change Earth's weather Cycles have shown signs of becoming increasingly more erratic severe and prolonged and though there is no blanket explanation for this change of weather patterns human-induced global warming is a major underlying Factor increased human consumption of fossil fuels since the industrial revolution has led to more greenhouse gases being released such as carbon dioxide and methane into Earth's atmosphere this has contributed to climate change in the form of increased global temperatures which can then affect How likely and how intense an extreme weather event can be the causality between global climate change and individual extreme weather event varies from event to event based on the type of weather the location time of year and how intense widespread and long it is however not all events are becoming more likely and severe some may be decreased in Chance by climate change or may not be changed much and changes are irregular across the world foreign what are some examples of extreme weather there are four main examples of extreme weather heat waves wildfires droughts and increased rainfall heat waves in many parts of the world are getting hotter more frequent and lasting longer and this is a result of human cause climate change hot spells have more than doubled in duration in the past 50 years and it's estimated that heat waves are 10 times more likely now according to the UK's Met Office increased heat has contributed to more regular and extensive Wildfire seasons in some areas of all continents this is because more moisture is drawn out of the earth and vegetation by more frequent and intense heat waves this then provides ideal kindling conditions for wildfires human activities such as Forest management and ignition sources are also important causal factors for these events droughts are becoming more common and more severe in some areas due to climate change there are two main ways this happens firstly through evaporation as the atmosphere warms more evaporation from the land occurs secondly through rainfall individual rainfall events are becoming heavier across the world falling in shorter and more intense bursts this heavier rain is more likely to saturate the ground and run directly into rivers rather than sustaining soil moisture and groundwater Reserve during more moderate rainfall overall the combination of more evaporation more sporadic heavier rainfall and less average downpours make dry spells more common in drought prone regions and seasons droughts put added pressure on Water Supplies as demand increases from people in agriculture which can lead to shortages human Water Management can also impact the likelihood of droughts increased rainfall has affected most of the world due to human-course climate change typically hot weather creates moisture and water vapor in the air which turns into droplets to create rain the warmer it becomes the more Vapor there is in the atmosphere this results in more droplets and heavier rainfall sometimes in a shorter space of time and over a small area this increased rainfall worsens flooding which can damage infrastructure and contaminate groundwater making it unsafe to drink however flooding can also be caused by human factors such as water management and defenses how can we lessen this impact scientists and experts have warned that if we want to reduce the worst consequences of climate breakdown we need to limit global warming to 1.5 degrees Celsius this target was written into the 2015 Paris agreement a legally binding treaty that 196 parties agreed to uphold the goal is to limit global warming to well below 2 degrees Celsius preferably to 1.5 degrees celsius compared to pre-industrial levels this Baseline was partly chosen because it's the earliest period with near Global observations in order to keep temperatures under 1.5 degrees Celsius dramatic changes need to be made namely Global CO2 emissions must be at half of their 2010 Levels by 2030 and at Net Zero or as close to no total carbon emissions as possible by 2050. the 1.5 degrees Celsius Target is increasingly Moving Out Of Reach an extreme weather is continuing to become more frequent and prevalent globally these multiple climate impacts will likely worsen a host of issues people around the world are currently facing like food insecurity damaged infrastructure induced migration and constrained resources however there is still hope that we can minimize the destructive cycles of extreme weather but in order to do so we must focus on limiting any further human impact on our Global Climate immediately [Music]
